author: punnk

description.text:
These are shelf supports for a Stack-On GCB-900 safe. I've read some reviews of the shelves being weak and bowing/caving in over time due to weight on them, so I made these two simple supports as a fail safe.

Supports are 5.875" tall ( from bottom of unit to underside of first shelf, including foam bottom pad ), and 4.125" tall ( from top of bottom shelf to underside of top shelf ). The landings are 1.5" wide, and the parts are 6" deep.

My plan is to put them in the center of of the unit, and tape in place if the friction fit is too sloppy.

Supports were printed on low quality, 25% infill, and with no support to try and minimize cleanup. The underside of the support if is a little jagged, but with some sanding and a clear coat applied they will be functional and look good.

description.text:
You might have some gadgets like cell phones, cameras, etc. that are useless now - either because they are obsolete or broken.
Before you throw them into the trash you can reuse Li-ion battery for your projects. Sometimes they are still in good condition, typically there is also a charger that was included with the product.

Purpose of this adapter is to make reuse of such batteries easy. You just print it and put standard Molex 2510 compatible connector contacts inside.

Adapter is fully customizable so it should not be a problem to customize one for your particular battery type. And you can publish it for the community then :-)

This is a test hypocycloid gear for aprox 64:-1 reduction on a NEMA 17 stepper motor.

The extra components needed for this are:
  • NEMA 17 stepper motor
  • Metric 608ZZ bearings
    • The output has 3x M3 holes with hex heads for coupling. The planet gear may require a little sanding to make the bearings fit inside it, as will the offset shaft. The slot in the offset shaft is for a tiny woodscrew or self tapping screw in case you need more friction against the stepper shaft. If the stepper has a flat section on it, make sure it's facing away from the bearings so the spacing isn't affected. I have tested this design though not thoroughly. Also I've tweaked the design from the first print, still need to test changes. Video of an earlier version working: http://youtu.be/D_uAb-iEb_Q Updated to put parts centered and correct way up for printing. Added a zip of the original Solidworks files (sorry, the naming doesn't match up) Added zip of STL files and Parasolid - this set does not include the backlash required for extrusion printed parts. CREDIT:
    Thanks to Alex Lait who wrote the python Hypocycloid cam generator: http://www.zincland.com/hypocycloid
    (My copy is now horribly mutilated with metric and automatic naming)

comments.text: If you are still interested in feedback.  I printed and built one of these gear boxes and tested it to failure with the motor un-powered.  I was curious how much the gear would hold up.  It failed in two places.  The main failure was a couple "teeth" broke off the planetary gear above the bearing. The other failure point was a some distortion of the output gear.   If you are interested I would thicken the wall above the bearing on the planetary gear and thin the overall housing on the inside and use that extra thickness to thicken the outside of the output side. But it is a wonderful gearbox. I have it connected to a 68 oz in motor and will test to see how well it can repeatedly lift the theoretical 22ft lb it would produce.

description.text: This is set of organizational office supplies made to look like popular emojis. The devil emoji has a flat space between its horns which can be used as a mini table-top to rest small things on (such as USB's or erasers). The shocked emoji has a hole cut into the top to act as a pen or pencil holder. Both of these rest in bases (which fit together like puzzle peices) to keep them stable and upright. These should be used in conjunction with Emoji Set 2. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1964984

Recent analysis by the Staples finance department has concluded that sales for desktop organization products have declined in recent years. The company would like to ramp up their profits in this area by enhancing the aesthetic nature of these products.
Your group of three has been hired to design a set of theme-based organizational products. Your team will design a set of office supplies that are tied together with a common theme. You must be able to justify the theme that connects the products together. The idea is that the customer will not want to buy just one; they will want to buy the whole set.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/aPlS4e6qRmo
this is not mine to call my own this a remix from the original creator i just made a landscape version instead of a verticle one

This is version 2. A newer and better version is available as a standalone or part of the 4 Controllers Stand

The idea is to create 4 of these so 4 controllers can be kept on the table. Those stands should be stackable hence the locking at the back. Two plates (one on top and one on bottom) in the middle between the four stands should be able to hold these together. The model should be easily printable laying on its side to ensure internal stability.

Version 1 was not stable enough as it used the same angle Clem_golgoth's original uses. The angle the controller lies has been modified. It goes 15 degrees more to the back now.
Laying backwards would require some more space so the 4 controllers don't touch each other. 2 cm were added. Also an edge was added to the front to possibly give additional support to the controller.
The more length - the more material used for printing. Introducing more holes to reduce that.

Project 3: 2-D Art Problem Statement: With a partner, you will design a “2D” placard using Solidworks. You and your partner will have the same design which meets the constraints below, and you will EACH use Solidworks to create your design. Constraints:
No error messages
Part should be CENTERED about the origin
Demonstrate efficient use of construction lines
Demonstrate efficient use of automatic and manual relations
Demonstrate efficient use of Smart Dimensions Project Requirements: You and your partner should develop an agreed upon plan for recreating your figure:
Each person will draw a 1x scale front view of your design:
Each person’s drawing will contain ALL dimensions and reference lines used.
A bulleted/numbered list of the order you will create your sketch to be updated as you work through completing your design.
This plan MUST be approved before you begin making your figure in Solidworks.
Once you begin creating your models, you and your partner MUST work together, staying at the same pace. DO NOT move on to the next step of your plan until you’ve checked in with your partner and you are BOTH ready to proceed to the next step. Each person should submit their completed Solidworks file at the end of the project.

description.text:
This stem-shaped holder for paperclips and tiny trinkets was created using the program Solidworks. Leaf extensions store small objects and snap on to the separate stem/branch base part.
To be used in conjunction with the Pyramid Hanger. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1968058

Our original design included a stem stand similar to our final design but we thought we would layer stoppers and leaf parts. The stoppers would be tight fixtures around the stem to hold the leaves in place. The problem with this design was the fact that the leaves could not rotate and there were too many parts since the plan included stopper parts and leaf parts. Our new design was more effective since the leaves could snap on and be taken off with ease. In the old design, leaf parts are restricted to their positions as they layer on the stem part. In our final design, the snap on leaves are more effective because they can attach to any part of the stem

This is a case I designed for the Arduino for my Solar Tracker ( http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xj-fqcNuqIk ) project. It holds an Arduino, a custom stepper motor control board and a 20X4 LCD module. The outer dimensions are 4.875" X 4.5" X 2.75". The interior dimensions are 4.625" X 4.00" X 2.275". It features a removable top cover and wire passthrus on the sides. The Arduino USB and power holes are located to allow room for double-sided foam under the Arduino.

This design is intended to be cut on a laser cutter from 3mm acrylic. This fluorescent green from US Plastic Corp. http://www.usplastic.com/catalog/item.aspx?itemid=37473&catid=442 is awesome looking. I used a Full Spectrum Hobby Deluxe laser cutter - power 51%, speed 100%. The tolerances are very tight. The pieces lightly press fit together. The exploded view should give you a general idea for assembly. You know, "Tab A into slot B" etc. 1) Insert the sides (with the wire pass thrus on top) and the bottom plate into the backplate.
2) Then press faceplate onto the other end of the sides and bottom.
3) Insert the corner brackets into the slots on the faceplate and then pivot into the slots on the sides. This takes a little finesse (not the shampoo!).
4) Place the spacers on top of the corner brackets and carefully apply the plastic welder to the seams of the corner brackets.
5) Check that all tabs are fully seated into slots
6) Carefully apply plastic welder to all seams. Avoid contact with other areas as SameStuff welder will "melt" the plastic wherever it touches. Seems to be more of a problem when room temp is 80F or above.
7) Do not glue lid! Otherwise you will have a nice empty box!
8) Carefully tap 8-32 threads into corner bracket holes.
9) Enjoy! The units on the files are inches so to load in say Inkscape you need to import with a scale of 25.4 to convert to mm.
8) Tap 8-32 threads in the corner bracket holes.
9) Enjoy. The body is "glued" using Micro-Mark SameStuff Professional plastic welder. The top is the only thing not "glued". It is removable and secures with 8-32 screws. Make sure you carefully tap the holes in the corner spacers - don't just try and "tap" it by driving in the screws - acrylic cracks easily. When removing the top cover lift gently until you just clear the top of the faceplate and then slide cover toward the front until the tabs come out of the slots. If you lift too hard or far you will crack the backplate. If you use a file to put a slight bevel on the bottom edge of the top cover tabs the lid goes on and off easier.

remixed_from.author: Grogo666
remixed_from.title: Reach3D left holder for BL Touch

description.text:
This is the latest version of Marlin 1.1.0 RC8 modified for the Reach3D printer

http://www.reach3dprinters.com

with two different height sized BLT height blocks for different kind of nozzles. Use the 5mm for standard 5mm brass nozzles and the 10mm for extra large sized ones.

You will need to download the left bracket part from here and also have 2 x M2 20mm bolts & 2 x M2 nuts for mounting the BLTouch > http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1925459
plus the latest version of Arduino IDE (1.1.6.8) > www.arduino.cc

Instructions (from Grogo666):

Upload firmware to Reach3D using Arduino app. Run USB cable to printer with slicer ie. Simplify3D, MatterControl, Cura etc.

In slicer terminal run:
M280 P0 S10 (to raise BLT pin)
M280 P0 S90 (to drop BLT pin)

M280 P0 S120 enters in test mode (up/down) Perfom M402 to stop it.
If BLT enters error mode (blinking red) issue a M280 P0 S160 to shut alarm off.

Do a G28 - should probe center of bed twice, full speed and then slow speed.
Then do G1 Z0 - position won't be good so you need to correct Z-Offset.

Do M851 command, should return Z OFFSET
Move BED Y-35 & X -10 to put the nozzle where the BLTouch just probed.
Get a sheet of paper under nozzle, and do 0.1 steps, and level as you wish going down progressivly, note the distance on your LCD screen.

Software Endstop in FW has been deactivated so that the Z can actually have negative values.

Once the nozzle is correct height for you, issue:
M851 Z-xx.xx where xx.xx is the distance you noted
Immediately issue M500 to store in EEPROM
Do a M851 or M501 you should see the value you entered for Z-Offset

Do a G28
Do a G29, it will probe 9 points on your bed.

Now you are ready to print with the BLTouch!

title: E3D V6 hotend retainer clip for QuBD One/Two/ThreeUp Printers

description.text:
QuBD apparently now ships E3D V6 hotends instead of anUbis. I saw E3D in action on a friend's TwoUp and it works so much better than anUbis that I also made the change. E3D has a much bigger groove than anUbis, so the stock mounting mechanism with two screws results in wobbling. I used tape to fill the groove, which worked fine.

However, I print a lot and have found that my E3D parts become loose every so often. You can kind of tighten it in place, but it's cumbersome and places strain on the printhead. Removing the hotend doesn't take long, but it's a pain and I could see that my head won't last long if I keep taking these screws out all the time.

This retainer clip fixes the wiggle and enables hotend removal without taking the head apart. It is kept in place by the M4 tensioning screw. You will need to replace the two long M3 screws that hold the hotend by shorter M3 screws (10-12mm) to keep the relevant parts together and don't obstruct the clip.

I place no restrictions whatsoever on this design - feel free to use and modify as you see fit.

Printer:

TwoUp

Rafts:

No

No

Notes:

I printed this in PLA using 0.2mm layer height, but you can use pretty much anything.

Lesson instructions Name: __
Project #4: Office Supply Storage Problem Statement:
Recent analysis by the Staples finance department has concluded that sales for desktop organization products have declined in recent years. The company would like to ramp up their profits in this area by enhancing the aesthetic nature of these products.
Your group of three has been hired to design a set of theme-based organizational products. Your team will design a set of office supplies that are tied together with a common theme. You must be able to justify the theme that connects the products together. The idea is that the customer will not want to buy just one; they will want to buy the whole set. OPTIONS:
Pencil holder that can securely hold at least 5 pencils
Expo marker holder than can securely hold at least 4 markers
Pen holder that can securely hold at least 5 pens
Tape dispenser that will hold and cut a roll of scotch tape
Anything you can get approved by your project manager! Constraints:
You will be constructing an actual size model of your product in Solidworks
It should be cool to look at and unique - a conversation starter. An individual walking by would do a double take to more closely examine the amazingly interesting item you’ve created.
There should be a theme that ties the products together
It should have multiple extrusions for detail
It should contain examples of ALL THREE main features: revolve, sweep, loft
It takes advantage of the following: circular pattern, linear pattern, mirror
It takes advantage of at least one of the following: filleting, chamfering
Each piece should fit within a 10cm x 10 cm x 10cm cube
Should be 3D printable

3D and 2D sketches of your ideas (upload pictures)

description.text:
We’ve been having some issues with our new 3D printer nozzle clogging. We believe this is due to a lack of air being blown over the fins in the latest Spiderbot printer. The fan only blows across one third of the cooling fins. We designed and printed a duct that redirects the air across all of the fins.

The fan is simply press-fit on top of the duct. The part is made of two support-free pieces that can be super-glued together. If your fan doesn't fit tight enough, try adding a drop of superglue to the mating piece.

Note: The foil material shown in the picture is a heat shield we added to protect the part and cooling fins from the heat radiating off the hot-end.

title: Hot Wheels High Speed Merge Track

description.text:
Connect this 3 piece high speed merge track into your existing hot wheels race track loop and launch your cars onto the track loop at high speed.

Print several and use them to create a sophisticated looping/merging race track.

Most merge tracks cannot handle high speed vehicles and the cars usually jump the track. Not this one. It is in 3 pieces of 150mm each for a total of 450mm. This is the exact size of two small/medium lengths of hot wheels track so it can be aligned within your track layout.

The track will hold the cars in the lane even at high speeds and provides a smooth transition to the next piece of track or car booster.

This piece will significantly expand what you can do with your hot wheels track layout.

You will need to print one each of the merge track sections and 14 of the trackguides. Use an Exacto type razor knife to smooth the trackguide studs and the holes that the trackguide studs go into. I glued the studs in with a little super glue.

In the picture you can see some of my trackguides were printed in white, some in blue

This is a Rubik's Cube themed pencil sharpener designed in solidworks. The sharpener is not built in, however most small hand held sharpeners should fit in the slot. The stand acts as a holder for the shavings so you don't have to always be near a trash can when you're using it. The curved design was based off of the MoYu Aolong v1. The corners on every piece are curved as to prevent lock ups while solving fast on a normal cube, however because this is not functional the curves are purely aesthetic.

I modeled this daffodil in sculptris awhile back and discovered it looks pretty cool with an LED shining in it. For awhile I was playing around with some solar LED path lights and trying to create a solar lamp you could set in your window that resembled a potted plant.
Update: Added new pictures for a better illustration of the solar light as potted plant idea.

I've included the original complete model in case someone wants to do something else with it but it doesn't have the hole I cut through the base with openscad so it won't work for putting a light in it. I recommend printing the base and the bell separately to cut down on the support material required. Then you'll want to glue the two pieces together and for that I recommend this product, http://www.loctiteproducts.com/p/cntct_isns/overview/Loctite-Stikn-Seal-Indoor-Adhesive.htm I know people like to use acetone to bond parts together but I've found this stuff to work quite well and I don't have to worry about ventilating my work space.

comments.text:
Thanks for the art work. I made a number of Daffodil light for my wife, she loves them!
Dave,
KI4PSR

author: ahutch328

description.text:
The shaker is an easy way to keep in rhythm. And to give a nice feeling for some songs.  
If you have ideas about an instrument that you would like to have and is possible to print. Contact with us, and we will design it.  
Plabs 3D

I recommend for the lid an 80% infill or 100% so you ensure that the thread doesn't break. For the body no need for so much infill. 50% will be great. Anyway, you can try with less infill, as the sound will change and you could like it more. your choice...  
The 2 parts join up perfectly. I made them 2mm different so with printing precisions still made good mechanism. and I was amazed how perfect does it work.  
To improve the model, you can make a TPE or Soft PLA circle so the enclosure of both parts becomes airtight.  
Y filled mine with rice. But you can also try with lentils, peas, cents, or whatever you can imagine. Then...experiment with the sound and enjoy the music!!!  
If you have any instrument ideas, come to us and we will try to design them.  
Cheers from Plabs 3D

comments.text: Nice design! Idea - why not to make a foot shaker? Would be great to have it sound with my didgeridoo =)
comments.author: MonZon

comments.text: Thank you. How would you like to attach it to your foot? if you want to send me a drawing of what you imagine, I will design it for you... and obviously also for me. I also play a bit of didgeridoo. To send me something, you can send it to [email protected]

description.text:
The Bowling Ball Tape Dispenser is a part designed to provide an object to hold, dispense, and cut a roll of tape as accessible. It was created using the Solidworks program and consists of 5 different pieces that connect together.

The tape dispenser portion of the object consists of two parts. The tape should be placed on the larger part and then connected to the rectangular part. The entire contraption should then be inserted into the two holes located on the top of the bowling ball. The rectangular prism is the tape cutter and has an indentation on the tip where the small metal component of a store-bought tape dispenser can fit.

As an added bonus function, the holes located on the ball can also be used for storing small office supplies like paperclips, pushpins, etc. It is supposed to go in conjunction with the Pencil Holder Pin and Pin Stand located here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1965445

Problem Statement:

This is a solidworks generated model based of a sea anemone and functions as a pencil holder. It consists of sweeps, circular patterns, cut extrudes, revolved cuts, and a loft. We used a circular pattern on the sweeps to rotate them around the central tube. In all it has 19 tubes, which serve to hold pencils. This object was created within the dimensions 10 by 10 by 10, and it can fit in the palm of your hands. The tubes serve to hold the pencils. This is part of a set. The octopus tape dispenser (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1965379), and the flashdrive surfboard holder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1965307), are all part of the ocean set.
The concept of the small tubules were incorparated as a part that would serve as a pencil holder. This model served as an inspiration. Here's the link:http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:73489

title: Microcentrifuge tubes Multi-decapper
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A useful tool if you are dealing with hundreds of samples. Spares you the sore thumb! Feel free to modify/improve the design to suit your own needs. Printed in PLA.
Printing advice: At least 2 or 3 shells, 50-80% infill. Works pretty well. Both hands are needed for it to work properly (picture is for illustration purpose only!). Useful tip: Secure the decapper's pivot point firmly at the back of tubes' caps with both hands and twist upward to open the caps. Works like a charm!

comments.text: Hope you will find this useful! Feel free to modify/improve the design.

print_settings.Notes:: After the test, I printed four at the time using sequential printing with simplify3d. I really love this feature.

description.text:
My girlfriend has lots of paper rolls in her office. She just wanted to have some shelf bracket without boards on, but she needed something to ensure that the paper rolls did not roll over the edge.

Therefore these edge thingies. They are designed for millarco shelf brackets (I have seen them several other names though). I have no idea if something similar exists somewhere outside Denmark, but else this design might just serve as inspiration.

The "thingies" are designed for 3.5mm screws.

(This style shelf brackets: http://www.xl-byg.dk/produkter/bolig-fritid/hyldeknaegte/rack-system/millarco-pulverlakeret-track-system-rack-system-hvid-17cm.htm)

Update 20170115: Added a version with 20mm high knob. The original design is 35mm high.

Notes:

I printed one lying and one standing just for test and comparison. I prefer the lying version. It is probable stronger that way, it printed much faster (23 minutes vs 65) and finally the standing version really highligted the z-wobble problem on the prusa I printed them on.

After the test, I printed four at the time using sequential printing with simplify3d. I really love this feature.

print_settings.Notes:: I recommend trying the connector parts first - the design is tuned to MY printer, which uses a 0.6 nozzle, so it might be that with a different nozzle the connector doesn't sit tight enough.

remixed_from.author: Dr_Craw
remixed_from.title: freestanding spool attachment for Wanhao Duplicator i3, Cocoon Create, Maker Select i3 3D printers.

title: [Experimental] Freestanding spool attachment, cut in half

description.text:
This is a minor remix of the original, I've cut it in half and added connectors that should splice it together well enough.

I've tried to print the original five times, every time the filament started peeling off the printbed - no doubt it wasn't aligned properly enough.

So, instead of finetuning the printer, like any sensible person would have done, I decided to change the design, so it wouldn't need as much space, hopefully printing better :-D

Good news: it did. The prototype is currently holding the spool. (I moved the cut a bit, to make both sides closer to the same length, though the male part is still a bit longer).

Note: since it's cut in half, it's less stable. So far it holds (three days now), but if your printer is able to print the original, go for it.
Don't let your printer unsupervised, remember that many of the filaments can burn and the printer does get hot!

[edit]Well, the spool stand still holds, but a full spool shouldn't be at the end of the bar, that probably won't hold forever :-(

Printer:

Wanhao i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

I recommend trying the connector parts first - the design is tuned to MY printer, which uses a 0.6 nozzle, so it might be that with a different nozzle the connector doesn't sit tight enough.

Tinkercad link

https://tinkercad.com/things/25IBJsZb0N0

description.text:
One-piece iPad stand with two angles. Can be printed for iPad Pro (pictured) with 150mm diameter, or smaller iPads by changing the diameter.

The stand is parametric. Using the OpenSCAD file, can be printed on a MakerBot Mini, for use with an iPad Mini using 100mm diameter. Yes, Mini begets Mini! I hope mini people find this useful.

The OpenSCAD files are found here:
https://github.com/thrasher/ipad-mini-stand

Write.scad found here:
https://github.com/rohieb/Write.scad
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16193/

Update: The inside-sphere writing has been removed in the .stl posted here.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator Mini

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Use 3 shells to give the outside strength, and to allow the overhang in the middle of the sphere to print better. Note: the maximum build size of a MakerBot Mini is 10cm, which will work for holding an iPad Mini, or for 40 deg angles, a regular iPad Air. Use the OpenSCAD file to change these values, create a new .stl, and print.

Originally designed to hold an iPad for my wife. She wanted to easily read, at a steeper angle than was provided by the iPad's case/cover. I wanted to support the iPad, but also other tablets, with or without covers. I also wanted to be able to add custom text, but on the inside of the sphere, so it wasn't overt. The Write.scad library works for this, though a little hack is needed for writing on the inside of a sphere.

This is a Taj Mahal model that is also a pencil holder. The 4 towers hold one pencil each and the center dome can hold multiple pencils. This project was done with theme in mind, and our other project was a Eiffel Tower paper clip holder.
Link here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1961844
This picture is how we found the measurements and the basic shape and outling for the Taj Mahal.

Problem Statement:
Recent analysis by the Staples finance department has concluded that sales for desktop organization products have declined in recent years. The company would like to ramp up their profits in this area by enhancing the aesthetic nature of these products.
Your group of three has been hired to design a set of theme-based organizational products. Your team will design a set of office supplies that are tied together with a common theme. You must be able to justify the theme that connects the products together. The idea is that the customer will not want to buy just one; they will want to buy the whole set. OPTIONS:
Pencil holder that can securely hold at least 5 pencils
Expo marker holder than can securely hold at least 4 markers
Pen holder that can securely hold at least 5 pens
Tape dispenser that will hold and cut a roll of scotch tape
Anything you can get approved by your project manager!

This is a tape dispenser created within the chosen theme of "chickens".
The tape roll goes on the knob which is then inserted into the back of the tape dispenser body.
This tape dispenser requires a small metal razor for cutting the tape which should be placed in the thin slot already made on tape dispenser.
The chicken tape dispenser was created as a office supplies project with a chicken theme and is meant to go along with the egg earbud holder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1965397
These are original sketch plans for the tape dispenser. These are sketch plans for the knob part of the tape dispenser.

description.text: The complete ocean set consists of the pencil sea anemone holder(http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1965259), this is the link if you want to check it out. This is a solidworks generated model based of an octopus, its primary function is to serve as a tape dispenser. The whole set consists of the body(Octopus), the flash drive surfboard holder(http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1965307). In this set...There is a small cylinder that holds the tape in the body. The small cylinder fits between the two notches in the main cutting the body. The This small cylinder can detach from the body, allowing for a person to be able to take an empty tape roll off and attach a new roll of tape. It consists eight arms, with one arm serving as the arm that holds a piece of metal that cuts tape. The model is a simple model, consisting of lofts, circular patterns, extrudes, sweeps, and fillets.
Octopus Tape Dispenser This was model was generated in the classroom where students thought of this idea. Huge shout out to Mr. Tessier for greatly helping the students produce this model.

An individual walking by would do a double take to more closely examine the amazingly interesting​ item you’ve created. ● There should be a theme that ties the products together ● It should have multiple extrusions for detail ● It should contain examples of ALL THREE main features: revolve, sweep, loft ● It takes advantage of the following: circular pattern, linear pattern, mirror ● It takes advantage of at least one of the following: filleting, chamfering ● Each piece should fit within a 10cm x 10 cm x 10cm cube ●Should also be 3d printable

This is a Rubik's Cube themed tape dispenser. The basis for this idea came from looking at the size of a normal role of tape. We noticed that we could fit it in a layer of a Rubik's Cube and potentially have it function if we made a hole in one of the edge pieces. So we did. there is a large circular hole in the center that acts as the holder and the top comes off so you can take the tape out or put it in. The hole at the top is where the tape comes out and a little slot for a blade since we can't print one at school.
WARNING: The 4 prongs that are on the top piece may be too big and may make it diffucult to pull the two pieces apart after putting it together. As you can tell I had this problem and I highly recommend sanding them down before attempting to assemble the dispencer.

author: ZZodiac01

description.text:
This took some work to get it work function properly, I tell ya... Total print time for me was 8 hours, 56 minutes. The hardest part of the print for your machine will be the bearings as they are print-in-place with no support. Simply (and carefully) break them loose with a small screwdriver after the print is done.

I will say it doesn't work exactly perfect. But that I expect is due to the small size of the ball bearings and the fact that they don't have a lot of mass. If they were SLS printed in metal, or replaced with small ceramic/steel bearings (2.79mm, or close. You've got about .41mm clearance on both sides in the bi-stable track), I imagine the function would be much more predictable.

EDIT 1 : Added alternate lids with different Triquetras on the top for a bit of design flare. Might need support to print these unless your bridging is boss-like.

EDIT 2 : Geocaching lids! Groundspeak official, as well as the G-compass. Most certainly will need supports.

EDIT 3 : Traditional Yggdrasil (Tree of Life) lid. Needs support.

title: Maker Box Filament Spool - 180mm total diameter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I've been with Maker Box for a period of time, but the loose filament poses a challenge. I tried many different filament spools, but I found that none were well suited to the Maker Box filament. I tried many, but I was never happy. Some were too small spool size, so the filament would spring open even after leaving them on the spool taped in place. Others I wouldn't print because it was way too much material cost to build. I tried using spent filament rolls from 0.5kg and 1kg rolls, but they usually have smaller spool size interiorly, so they too would spring open and not wind nicely.

So, at the end of the day, I decided to engineer my own. I had some design guidelines in my head. First off, it had to work with my filament stand. Not only the core needed to be small enough to fit my stand's rod, but narrow enough to fit alongside another filament roll for dual color prints. I wanted it to be low filament usage. I also wanted a hole to put the filament through for winding, and a lower filament guard to prevent it from skipping out when you were winding. My design came out nice, and has withstood two full windings and uses. The diameter of the spool is just a hair bigger than the widest part of the Maker Box filament, and I did this so the wind would be wound slightly tight on the spool, but still come back off and be able to go back into the bag. It splits open and the filament comes off easily.

Some key notes on this design; The core where your rod passes through, does not go together, and I left them shorter. I found that it would create an alignment issue for trying to get it all to snap together, but I still left more of a 'collar' inside to reduce wear and make alignment better.

There are two versions currently; A 20mm core, and a 30mm core. If you'd like a different size, let me know. It's easy to change.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

EG1+

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Recommended settings:

  • 0.3mm layer height
  • 0.5mm layer width (Except first layer - Use whatever you need for adhesion)
  • 100% infill
  • 3 perimeter layers

If you want to do this at any other layer height, I don't see any issues coming from this. However, I DO encourage using the 0.5mm layer width due to how the two halves fit together.

My printer worked best on this with 20mm/s 125% width first layer, 85mm/s balance.

As long as you have zits/blobs under control, these will push together with little issue, but still friction-fit. If you feel they are too loose, I recommend 2 pieces of tape opposite each other on the inside of the spool.

You can slide the filament off smoothly once you split the spool. Have not tested if you can load directly, but I do recommend winding the filament on by hand to ensure a good wind that won't tangle.
Used Fusion 360 to design this. I've been learning parabolic design for a while, and this was my first serious project with it.

comments.text: I have a question on what could be possible with this design.  A bunch of us get the MakerBox samples each month and the plastic is rolled and put into ziplock bags.  Could this design be altered just a bit to add more side pieces in various spots within the roll?  Basically, I'm wanting one roll that snaps together and I can roll 4, 5, or even 6 different filament samples divided into their own section, but all held within the size of a normal 1kg roll.
comments.author: Gimp_Geek

comments.text: See my make for further comments but suffice to say this Thing has saved me from tanglesd filament sample woes. It's pretty flimsy but that allows it to print very fast (and if it breaks you can just print another) and it's perfectly adequate for the purpose. I looked at quite a few others but very few have such a large winding diameter and this is essential for sample coils since they unwind if you try and force them onto a smaller spool. Great work, especially minimising the print time.

description.text: This pool table can hold up to six pencils. U can also play by using the ball and using the pencils as cues.

I made this piece out of appreciation and adoration of Doublade's complex and 2-dimensional figure. The piece has a flat base with multi-layered detail to show the intricate designing and process in making the piece. It is meant as a decoration piece and should be handled with caution, especially near the hands/ribbons.
Measurements and Planning

2-Dimensional Art Problem Statement: With a partner, you will design a “2D” placard using Solidworks. You and your partner will have the same design which meets the constraints below, and you will EACH use Solidworks to create your design. Constraints: Should have a flat back; detail will be on the front side
Should fit inside a box that is 10 cm x 10 cm when lying flat
Should be no more than 1 cm thick
Should be as detailed as possible
Detail will be made using sketches that are extruded to different heights
No error messages
Do not extrude contours - each feature should have its own sketch
Part should be CENTERED about the origin
Demonstrate efficient use of construction lines
Demonstrate efficient use of automatic and manual relations
Demonstrate efficient use of Smart Dimensions
Demonstrate efficient use of mirroring
Demonstrate efficient use of linear or circular patterns

This is a doorknob that I made over a 2 week span in class. Not all of the inside parts are present as of time constraints.

This is a brass and silver colored door knob made by Weiser

The task was to take an everyday object and reverse engineer it, (Take it apart). Then one was to take the parts, measure them and sketch them out in their engineering notebook. Next one was to take these drawings and create 3D models from them and put them together.

title: Christmas Tree Star
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Here is my Christmas tree star using an Arduino and WS2812. It prints with very minimal, if any, support material. Assembly was all light snap fit for me.

NOTE: The STL files were created in inches. Use a scale factor of 25.4 if you are using millimeters.

Print the following:
3X Star_Point_Default
2X Star_Point_Support
2X Star_Cap_Default
10X Star_Clip_Default
1X Star_PCBHolder_Default
1X Star_PCBHolder_Mate
1X Star_Base_Default

I also put a triangular piece of cardstock (template STL file included) in the middle of each point to minimize bleed.

Resolution:

.013in

Infill:

Solid

Notes:

My printer does 0.013" layer thickness and .026" width per pass. The points were designed with a wall thickness of .052" so that it would be printed with 2 passes.

Material used: "HATCHBOX ABS-1KG1.75-TWHT ABS 3D Printer Filament, Dimensional Accuracy +/- 0.05 mm, 1 kg Spool, 1.75 mm, Transparent White"

I used 10 WS2812 LEDs on PCBs, and soldered them in a row using bus wire, and then bent them in a circle.

For the Arduino program, I mostly used the FastLED example program "DemoReel100" and then I tweeked a few things.

Code is on github.
Video on youtube.

comments.text:
Just what I was looking for! Thank you!
but your print settings says Infill: solid !? shouldn't it be 0?
comments.author: Fireflynj

comments.text: The model is hollow already with a .052 wall thickness so that two passes should create the shell.
comments.author: Fireflynj

comments.text:
It is doing two passes, but with a .5 nozzle its has a gap between the two, (two thin walls) I can slip a piece of paper into the wall.
what size nozzle are you using? I had this happen before on something I designed and had to make wall thinner for it to touch each other. I tried infill: solid too.
comments.author: braclark

comments.text: I'm not sure of the nozzle, but it's set for 0.013" layer height which forces a 0.026" width per pass on my machine, which comes out to two passes and no gaps.
comments.author: Fireflynj

comments.text: Ok, that would be 0.33mm in height which is fine but the width is 0.66mm,  so I have to somehow either get mine to do 3 passes or make the object thinner.  I am printing as is for now, it comes out a little wavy and too flexible, but I want to improve it somehow for the next star.  you wouldn't happen to want to share the original file? or modify it for other users?, just the star default and support.  Thanks
comments.author: braclark

comments.text:
Thank you for the reply.
when I imported the object, the star point default was only 5mm tall, I scaled it 20x and printed a couple test parts and my printer did pretty good, the clips where a little challenging. but would like to know how big you did yours, to also make sure the pcb fits.
comments.author: braclark

comments.text: Sorry, I exported the stl file in inches, so you should scale it by 25.4.
comments.author: Fireflynj

description.text:
A simple two part enclosure for the Adafruit PowerBoost 1000C and 4400mAh battery.

Enclosure has an opening for the optional switch on the PowerBoost, thus allowing the "Power Pack" to be turned on and off.

Small holes allow monitoring of the "Power Packs" condition via the on-board PowerBoost LED's.

Printing both pieces with the large flat side down.

title: E3D Titan Extruder Mounting bracket for K8200

description.text: This bracket hasn't been designed for 3D printing. I milled it out of a piece of POM, but maybe someone can print it with support material and acceptable tolerances. Intention was mountig an E3D Titan extruder with hotend on to a Velleman K8200 3D-Printer achieving the original nozzel position. In addition I needed a short piece of the original Aluminium frame and an additional edge bracket.

comments.text: Excellent, printed perfectly. I printed it with the two mount screw recesses facing down, with supports. I have to modify this for dual extruder use on my CoreXY, but great template to start from.
comments.author: svenyonson

author: RolandSautner

description.text:
This eyepiece is used to collimate your newtonian / printonian telescope's primary and secondary mirrors. Inspired by this laser collimator,
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12624
but here there is no need to collimate the collimator ;-) . Use: several tutorials online, I especially like this one:
http://www.astro-baby.com/collimation/astro%20babys%20collimation%20guide.htm
check also this: http://www.atmsite.org/contrib/Carlin/collimation/kolli2.htm#mkcombination and http://www.skyandtelescope.com/howto/diy/3306876.html

This should be a close fit in a 1.25" eyepiece adapter like this one:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19200 Check your printer calibration with test_cheshire.stl (only 5 mm high), eventually modify the diameter in the openscad file and regenerate a stl. Print collimator_grid.pdf or dxf, cut, center and glue on the inner bevel. Enjoy! Also included a mask to mark the center of a 4.5" primary mirror.

remixed_from.author: StephS
remixed_from.title: Titan Extruder mount for Lulzbot Taz 6 with E3D V6 Hotend

title: Titan extruder mount for lulzbot taz4 and taz5, one fan

description.text:
This extruder is for the e3d Titan extruder. Thanks goes out to StephS on the great design. I modified to work with a taz4 or taz5. I removed the second fan because I rarely use one and when i do i mount on the right anywayz because the left doesn't have enough room. You need (4) 3mm threaded inserts and screws for attaching the 40mm fan to the duct/mount. You should be able to use any size motor as long as it fits on your taz.
This is a final product and is tested on my taz 4. just be carful when dialing in your hight and and the front right corner during large prints. the fan touches the bed clamps but its rare this happens and isn't fixable yet. I will fix this when i recieve my new fan and rework the design.

description.text:
I converted my direct driven printer to a 3mm Bowden. But now with more friction, because of the PTFE-tube, my filament grinding increased.

so I designed this Extruder with two hobbed bolts. And the special profile of the "hobbs" in the bolt.
and my filament grinding was gone.

you need:
6 x bearing 608
1 x bearing 6000
some M4 screws
some headless M3 screws
